text: I have not spent much time working with BAMs, but I'm going to have to in the next 6 months. I'm happy to spitball on the issues, though probably not competent (and don't presently have time to get competent) to implement solutions

elements.text: I have not spent much time working with BAMs, but I'm going to have to in the next 6 months. I'm happy to spitball on the issues, though probably not competent (and don't presently have time to get competent) to implement solutions

text: Okay. I don't have much time going forward, but have spent some time trying to learn the ropes.

elements.text: Okay. I don't have much time going forward, but have spent some time trying to learn the ropes.

text:
There are many, many small issues with these packages, so you might face some issues.
First, I never really worked with overlaps or indices with BAM files. Can you figure out what Indexes.jl actually does? It has no tests, that seems bad.

There are many, many small issues with these packages, so you might face some issues.
First, I never really worked with overlaps or indices with BAM files. Can you figure out what Indexes.jl actually does? It has no tests, that seems bad.

text: Also, if I could get you to try out my local branch of XAM where I've done extensive changes, that would be nice. There is little SAM functionality yet, though. If you need it, I'll prioritize it

elements.text: Also, if I could get you to try out my local branch of XAM where I've done extensive changes, that would be nice. There is little SAM functionality yet, though. If you need it, I'll prioritize it

text: In return, I can promise you some cool new features :)

elements.text: In return, I can promise you some cool new features :)

text: Can you tag me on an issue (or multiple issues as appropriate)? I can't look at this right away, but keeping them in my github queue is the likeliest to keep it active on my agenda
